paragraphs: George Chacko, Minhyuk Park, Vikram Ramavarapu, Ananth Grama, Pablo Robles-Granda, Tandy Warnow

We introduce an agent-based model (ABM) to simulate citation behavior in scholarly articles. Our model incorporates various factors influencing citation decisions, including preferential attachment, recency, paper quality, and relevance (which is proxied by the neighborhood of the paper). By simulating the citation process, we aim to understand the dynamics of citation networks and the emergence of influential papers within academic communities. The ABM allows us to explore how different strategies and behaviors impact the overall structure of citation networks.
Characterizing the Solution Space of Migration Histories of Metastatic Cancers with MACH2
Mrinmoy S Roddur, Vikram Ramavarapu, Abigail Bunkum, Ariana Huebner, Roman Mineyev, Nicholas McGranahan, Simone Zaccaria, Mohammed El-Kebir

Metastatic cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths. Understanding the migration history of metastatic cancers is crucial for developing effective treatment strategies. We present MACH2, an algorithm that infers the migration history of metastatic cancers given a clonal tree and bulk sequencing data from multiple tumor sites. MACH2 infers anatomic labels for internal nodes in the clonal tree and returns a solution space of migration histories. Clonal trees can be collapsed into migration graphs, which represent the migration events between different anatomical sites. Because of the potentially vast solution space of possible migration histories, we developed a visualization tool (MACH2-Viz) to explore and filter through the solution space given known prior knowledge.
Exploration of Multi-Lingual Community Structure in Scholarly Articles

During my time at the National Institute of Informatics (国立情報学研究所) in Tokyo, I explored how cross lingual citation can divide a network of citing publications into communities. We used a dataset of 7 million papers from a corroborated dataset across OpenCitations, CrossRef, and OpenAlex. Langdetect was used to identify the language of each publication, and a multilingual BERT-based model was used to identify the topics of each publication.

CM++ - A Pipeline for Well-Connected Community Detection
Minhyuk Park*, Yasamin Tabatabaee*, Vikram Ramavarapu*, Baqiao Liu, Vidya Kamath Pailodi, Rajiv Ramachandran, Dmitriy Korobskiy, Fabio Ayres, George Chacko, Tandy Warnow
Vikram Ramavarapu, Fabio Ayres, Minhyuk Park*, Vidya Kamath Pailodi, João Alfredo Cardoso Lamy, Tandy Warnow, George Chacko

Community detection is the process of partitioning a very large graph into smaller "meso-scale" subgraphs. The definition of a "good" community is very amorphous. As such we created a generalizable community detection pipeline that allows users to switch between stages of operations (community detection with their specified algorithm, size filtering, tree filtering, statistics computation). We also created a stage in the pipeline that "chisels" computed communities into well-connected communities (illustrated below) through pruning and mincut operations.
